thread.title: Nigel Farage talks Brexit and Theresa May before downing 'strongest pint in Wetherspoons'

author: Ian Johnson
title: Nigel Farage talks Brexit and Theresa May before downing 'strongest pint in Wetherspoons'
text:
Nigel Farage talks Brexit and Theresa May before downing 'strongest pint in Wetherspoons' The ex-UKIP leader spoke as he brings his Brexit Bus to the North East Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Nigel Farage has told ChronicleLive Theresa May is "kicking the can down the road" over Britain's Brexit deal.
The ex-UKIP leader spent Friday afternoon enjoying pints in a Gateshead Wetherspoons ahead of a rally at the Sage.
Stunned punters snapped selfies with the MEP. One called for him to be knighted for his role in Brexit.
But 28 months after his work to get Britain out the EU was seemingly done, he admits he didn't expect to still be campaigning.
And demanding MPs "get on with it", he warned politicians are doing "enormous harm" to the public's trust in the democratic process. Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage enjoys a pint at Wetherspoons in Gateshead Town Centre (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
"They don't want us to leave - the people have spoken but a big majority of our MPs do not want this to happen," he said.
"They are tied up with this idea that we are somehow safer and more secure inside Europe.
"They don't have the imagination and they don't have the courage to think of us as being the independent country we always were."
His double decker Brexit bus pulled up outside the Gateshead High Street post office on Friday where he was met with a mix of adoration and bewilderment.
Grinning leave voters shook his hand. Read More No-deal Brexit would do 'lasting damage' to North East, business leader says
Inside The Tilley Stone branch of Wetherspoons, as customers enjoyed 'Fish Friday', they dropped their forks for their phone to grab pictures of him.
Despite being largely absent from the political frontline since the referendum, his popularity with pockets of the public is still undeniable. Pro leave supporters wait for Nigel Farage to arrive in Gateshead Town Centre (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
And this week, he told a Bolton rally he was "back and 'ready to fight them again".
He's part of a cross-party coalition, touring the country, pushing the message that 'leave means leave'.
The others, Tory MP David Jones and Tony Blair's former Minsiter for Sport Kate Hoey, also addressed Friday's rally.
And Mr Farage accused MPs from both sides of letting the public down. Read More Homeless man kicked in face as he slept
"It is not just the Conservatives, it is Labour as well - they are backtracking on their promises," he said.
"And it isn't just the referendum, it is the General Election too - people were told we are going to respect the vote and it just hasn't happened.
"85 per cent of voters voted for parties (in the last General Election) who said 'we will deliver Brexit'.
"So the very thought that we've had to kick-start this campaign and get around the country again - it is happening for one simple reason: The result is being, bit by bit, betrayed." Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage out and about in Gateshead (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
Despite Farage's comments, YouGov polls published this week suggest the appetite for Brexit is fading.
With the benefit of hindsight, more people now believe we were wrong to decide leave.
Recently, David Milliband told ChronicleLive the Brexit the public were promised "doesn't exist".
Mr Farage fired back at that, claiming the public had been lied to by the EU for decades, branding them a "bunch of gangsters". Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage out and about in Gateshead (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
And regardless of appetite, he claims people are now more sick of just waiting.
This could intensify, he feels, after the EU said it was ready for a 'brex-tension' - and extend the post-Brexit transition period of 21 months.
"The public want us to get on with it, so the PM coming back yesterday having agreed to having another year of transition goes completely against what people want," said Mr Farage. Read More Watch Ian Lavery clash on Question Time as he defends Jeremy Corbyn and backs Brexit
"And talking about kicking the can down the road - effectively now we would be stuck in a transition period until the next general election when a different Government could come in and keep us in Europe forever."
"There's a campaign for a second referendum but the truth is, in this country, the truth for stating as we are is only about 20 per cent.
"I think if we did have a second referendum, the breach of trust between voters, the government and the loss of confidence in the entire democratic system, would do this country an enormous amount of harm." Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage out and about in Gateshead (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
A Wetherspoon's was always going to be friendly to Mr Farage. Founder Tim Martin has campaigned with him while the firm's in-house magazine, read by an estimated four million people, is staunchly anti-EU.
But so is Gateshead. It emphatically voted to leave.
And punters backed Farage.
"He would do a better job than Theresa May," claimed 74-year-old Ken Forrest.
"The way things are going with Europe, she's going to ruin it."
Another, Steve Jones, said: "It is a disgrace he hasn't been knighted yet.
"I voted leave and I'm proud of it - we will be better off."
Smoking a ciggie bought in Brussells, Farage agrees.
Downing a pint of 6.9% beer, which the bar;s boss insisted is the strongest they sell, Farage tells onlookers he picked it for a reason.
"We have a big job on our hands," he says to laughs and cheers. But not everyone is receptive. Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage enjoys a pint at Wetherspoons in Gateshead Town Centre (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
The Brexit bus is expected to arrive to protests in Harrogate on Saturday.
And a report in June by the business-based North East Brexit Group warns - economically - our region stands to lose the most following the UK's exit from the European Union.
David and Maureen Hall left the pub as Mr Farage arrived. He voted out while she voted to remain.
"I live in hope that the North East will be better off out," he said.
"I don't," she added.
